abstract: E-mails from the Federal Reserve indicate Bank of America’s executives were pressed to stay quiet about Merrill Lynch’s financial condition, a document written by House Republicans claims.
snippet: E-mails from the Federal Reserve indicate Bank of America’s executives were pressed to stay quiet about Merrill Lynch’s financial condition, a document written by House Republicans claims.
lead_paragraph: Alarm was rising inside the Federal Reserve.

headline.main: U.S. Saw Problems on the Way at Merrill
headline.print_headline: U.S. Saw Problems On the Way At Merrill

byline.original: By Louise Story and Jo Becker

abstract: E-mails from the Federal Reserve indicate Bank of America’s chief executive was pressed to stay quiet about Merrill Lynch’s financial condition, according to a memo from House Republicans.
snippet: E-mails from the Federal Reserve indicate Bank of America’s chief executive was pressed to stay quiet about Merrill Lynch’s financial condition, according to a memo from House Republicans.
lead_paragraph: E-mail messages from the Federal Reserve’s chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, and others at the central bank indicate that the chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, was under pressure to keep quiet about concerns over Merrill Lynch’s financial condition and complete the bank’s acquisition of the securities firm, according to a memo from House Republicans.

headline.main: E-Mails Show Fed Pressure on Bank of America
